description: WHY DID YOU MAKE THE PLASTICS INDUSTRY A CAREER CHOICE? The plastics industry encompasses all the areas of manufacturing which interested me in my early college days. WHAT IS YOUR FAVORITE SPE MEMORY?
text:
WHY DID YOU MAKE THE PLASTICS INDUSTRY A CAREER CHOICE?

The plastics industry encompasses all the areas of manufacturing which
interested me in my early college days. For example, to mold a plastic part,
one needs to understand everything from the polymeric selection process
(including additives and composites) to the steel choice for the injection
mold. Further, an engineer is required to design the mold tooling and
integrate mold actions and secondary operations such as robotics.

In my current role, I have the opportunity to design components, select
materials, perform CAD of molds and setup processing conditions at the press.
I enjoy the variety!

WHY IS IT IMPORTANT TO BE AN SPE MEMBER AS A YOUNG PROFESSIONAL?

The main reason I find SPE membership useful is the incredible network it
provides. The folks I've met through ANTEC[R] and other conference-related
activities have been invaluable in my career progression since my
undergraduate days. The SPE journals and conference proceedings have also been
a source of knowledge and education.

WHAT IS YOUR FAVORITE SPE MEMORY?

I really enjoyed ANTEC[R] 2011 in Boston. It was the first professional
conference that I attended, and I was really impressed with the overall
content. I was able to present a poster on the work I performed at the
University of Wisconsin, Stout, which I believe was well received. The
interactions I had with the professionals at that point reinforced the fact
that I made the right decision in my field of study.

WHAT ONE THING DO YOU WANT PEOPLE TO KNOW ABOUT YOU?

On March 9, 2020, my wife and I welcomed our first child into our family!
Perhaps a future SPE member--time will tell.

WHAT'S YOUR FAVORITE PLASTICS PRODUCT?

Tough question. I'm not sure I have an answer. I believe that plastics parts
help to enable excellent product designs and capabilities. Consumer-grade
power tools are a great example--without plastics components, I'm sure
construction and fabrication would be much more difficult and expensive.

WHAT'S THE BEST ADVICE YOU COULD GIVE SOMEONE NEW TO THE PLASTICS INDUSTRY?
Tour as many plastics-related facilities as you can; typically businesses are
excited to show interested potential colleagues around. There is a massive
variety of plastics processing equipment in the industry and you should try to
learn about all types. Often, in a multicomponent product assembly, the best
manufacturing path requires numerous operations. I found that the best way to
learn about something is to shadow someone with significant experience.

WHAT'S COOL ABOUT YOUR JOB?

First, the people. 3M has a large pool of highly intelligent, innovative
folks, who come up with some wild ideas. Being in the corporate labs, I have
the pleasure of trying to figure out how to reduce ideas to tangible products.

Second, the variety. 3M has a diverse product portfolio spanning nearly all
industries. I get to work on something new almost weekly, ranging from
consumer products to automotive and acoustics, and other products.

Third, the worldwide impact. 3M's products, such as those in personal safety
and medical solutions, are available around the globe, in every market. Items
like the N95 respirators, Avagard antiseptic, and Curos IV port disinfectors
are currently being leveraged by medical professionals and consumers to combat
the COVID-19 virus. Each of these is available thanks to some form of plastics
molding technology.

title: "I JOINED [SPE] DURING MY UNDERGRADUATE [STUDIES AT THE UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN, STOUT] AND HAVE BEEN A MEMBER SINCE.".
html:
WHY DID YOU MAKE THE PLASTICS INDUSTRY A CAREER CHOICE?

The plastics industry encompasses all the areas of manufacturing which interested me in my early college days. For example, to mold a plastic part, one needs to understand everything from the polymeric selection process (including additives and composites) to the steel choice for the injection mold. Further, an engineer is required to design the mold tooling and integrate mold actions and secondary operations such as robotics.

In my current role, I have the opportunity to design components, select materials, perform CAD of molds and setup processing conditions at the press. I enjoy the variety!

WHY IS IT IMPORTANT TO BE AN SPE MEMBER AS A YOUNG PROFESSIONAL?

The main reason I find SPE membership useful is the incredible network it provides. The folks I've met through ANTEC[R] and other conference-related activities have been invaluable in my career progression since my undergraduate days. The SPE journals and conference proceedings have also been a source of knowledge and education.

WHAT IS YOUR FAVORITE SPE MEMORY?

I really enjoyed ANTEC[R] 2011 in Boston. It was the first professional conference that I attended, and I was really impressed with the overall content. I was able to present a poster on the work I performed at the University of Wisconsin, Stout, which I believe was well received. The interactions I had with the professionals at that point reinforced the fact that I made the right decision in my field of study.

WHAT ONE THING DO YOU WANT PEOPLE TO KNOW ABOUT YOU?

On March 9, 2020, my wife and I welcomed our first child into our family! Perhaps a future SPE member--time will tell.

WHAT'S YOUR FAVORITE PLASTICS PRODUCT?

Tough question. I'm not sure I have an answer. I believe that plastics parts help to enable excellent product designs and capabilities. Consumer-grade power tools are a great example--without plastics components, I'm sure construction and fabrication would be much more difficult and expensive.

WHAT'S THE BEST ADVICE YOU COULD GIVE SOMEONE NEW TO THE PLASTICS INDUSTRY? Tour as many plastics-related facilities as you can; typically businesses are excited to show interested potential colleagues around. There is a massive variety of plastics processing equipment in the industry and you should try to learn about all types. Often, in a multicomponent product assembly, the best manufacturing path requires numerous operations. I found that the best way to learn about something is to shadow someone with significant experience.

WHAT'S COOL ABOUT YOUR JOB?

First, the people. 3M has a large pool of highly intelligent, innovative folks, who come up with some wild ideas. Being in the corporate labs, I have the pleasure of trying to figure out how to reduce ideas to tangible products.

Second, the variety. 3M has a diverse product portfolio spanning nearly all industries. I get to work on something new almost weekly, ranging from consumer products to automotive and acoustics, and other products.

Third, the worldwide impact. 3M's products, such as those in personal safety and medical solutions, are available around the globe, in every market. Items like the N95 respirators, Avagard antiseptic, and Curos IV port disinfectors are currently being leveraged by medical professionals and consumers to combat the COVID-19 virus. Each of these is available thanks to some form of plastics molding technology.
